questions.text: A child presented with itchy plaques over the neck, the bilateral popliteal and cubital fossa. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Atopic dermatitis

 

Explanation:

The image shows lichenified, scaly, and hyperpigmented plaques over the popliteal fossae (behind the knees).

The history of itching and involvement of flexural areas (neck, popliteal, and cubital fossae) is highly characteristic of Atopic Dermatitis (Eczema).

 

Atopic Dermatitis:

  • Common in children, associated with atopy (asthma, allergic rhinitis, eczema).
  • Hallmark features:
    • Chronic pruritus and inflammation.
    • Flexural involvement in children and adults.
    • Lichenification due to chronic scratching.
    • Infants: More likely to have cheeks, trunk, and extensor limb involvement.
  • Exacerbating factors: Irritants, allergens, weather changes, infections.

Diagnosis:

  • Clinical diagnosis based on chronic relapsing course and typical distribution.
  • No specific lab test required.
  • Elevated IgE levels may be seen but are not diagnostic.

Management:

  1. Moisturisation (Emollients) – cornerstone of therapy.
  2. Topical corticosteroids – for flare-ups (mild to moderate strength).
  3. Antihistamines – for pruritus relief.
  4. Avoid triggers (harsh soaps, allergens, irritants).
  5. Severe cases: Topical calcineurin inhibitors (Tacrolimus), systemic immunosuppressants if needed.

Dermatitis Herpetiformis (Option B) is incorrect because it presents as intensely itchy, grouped vesicles on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees, buttocks), not flexural areas. Strongly associated with coeliac disease.

Pemphigus Vegetans (Option C) is incorrect because a rare variant of pemphigus, characterised by moist, verrucous plaques in intertriginous areas (axilla, groin), unlike the dry, lichenified lesions seen here.

Psoriasis (Option D) is incorrect because psoriasis in children often affects extensor surfaces (knees, elbows), not flexures. Lesions are well-demarcated, erythematous plaques with silvery scales, unlike the ill-defined, lichenified plaques seen here.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis for a child who has displayed symptomless lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis, as depicted in the image of the forearm lesions below?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Lichen nitidus

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows multiple, tiny, discrete, dome-shaped, shiny papules on the forearm.

The history of symptomless lesions on the forearm and shaft of the penis is characteristic of Lichen Nitidus.

 

Lichen Nitidus:

  • Rare chronic inflammatory disorder.
  • Presents as multiple, asymptomatic, tiny, uniform, skin-coloured to hypopigmented, dome-shaped papules.
  • Common sites:
    • Forearms
    • Dorsum of hands
    • Shaft of the penis (pathognomonic location)
    • Trunk
  • Aetiology: Unknown, but associated with atopic dermatitis, Crohn’s disease, and lichen planus.
  • Diagnosis: Clinical; biopsy if needed shows lymphocytic infiltrate in a "claw clutching a ball" pattern.

Management:

  • No treatment required if asymptomatic.
  • If symptomatic, topical steroids, emollients, or calcineurin inhibitors can be used.
  • Usually self-limiting but may persist for months to years.

Lichen Planus (Option A) is incorrect because Lichen planus presents as violaceous, flat-topped, pruritic papules with Wickham’s striae. Usually involves flexor wrists, oral mucosa, and lower back but not commonly the shaft of the penis.

Scrofuloderma (Option C) is incorrect because it is a tuberculous skin infection that presents as cold abscesses and sinus tracts overlying lymph nodes or bones, not as discrete, shiny papules.

Scabies (Option D) is incorrect because scabies causes intensely pruritic papules, vesicles, and burrows, commonly found in finger webs, axillae, and genital areas. The absence of itching and burrows makes scabies unlikely.

questions.text: What is the diagnostic test used to identify allergic contact dermatitis which is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction caused by external substances?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Patch test

  • The patch test is a commonly used diagnostic tool for identifying the causative allergens in allergic contact dermatitis.
  • It involves applying small amounts of suspected allergens onto adhesive patches, which are then placed on the patient's skin (usually on the back). The patches remain in place for 48-72 hours.
  • The presence of erythema, vesiculation, or induration at the site of patch application indicates a positive reaction, suggesting sensitivity to the tested allergen.

Test Name

Method

Type of Allergy Detected

Skin Prick Test (SPT)

Small amounts of allergens are pricked into the skin

IgE-mediated (e.g., pollen, food, dust mites)

Intradermal Test

Allergen injected into the dermis

Drug, venom, or weak SPT allergens

Patch Test

Allergens applied on a patch and placed on skin

Contact dermatitis (e.g., metals, chemicals)

Serum IgE Test (RAST)

Measures allergen-specific IgE in blood

Food, environmental, drug allergies

 

Incorrect Options:

Radioimmunosorbent (RAST) (Option B): The RAST test is a blood test used to measure specific IgE antibodies in the serum. Allergic contact dermatitis is a delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction mediated by T-cells, and it does not involve IgE antibodies. Therefore, the RAST test is not appropriate for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis.

Eosin-5′-maleimide binding test (Option C): The eosin-5′-maleimide binding test is a laboratory test used to assess the presence of hereditary spherocytosis, a congenital hemolytic anemia. It is not relevant for diagnosing allergic contact dermatitis.

Nitroblue tetrazolium (NBT) test (Option D): It is primarily used in the diagnosis of chronic granulomatous disease, an inherited disorder characterized by defective neutrophil function. This test is not related to the diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with itchy lesions on her arm as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B: Atopic dermatitis

  • In this case, the patient's positive family history of asthma and pruritic lesions on flexural site increases the likelihood of atopic dermatitis
  • Atopic dermatitis, also known as eczema, is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and inflamed skin lesions.
  • It is commonly associated with a personal or family history of asthma, hay fever, or other allergic conditions.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Seborrhoeic dermatitis is a common, chronic, and relapsing skin condition characterized by red, scaly, and greasy patches, typically affecting areas rich in sebaceous glands such as the scalp, face, and upper trunk. It is not typically associated with a positive family history of asthma, making it less likely in this scenario.

Option C: Allergic contact dermatitis is an inflammatory skin reaction that occurs when the skin comes into contact with a specific allergen or irritant. It usually presents as a localized rash with redness, swelling, and itching. While it is possible for individuals with atopic dermatitis to develop allergic contact dermatitis, the patient's symptoms and family history are more suggestive of atopic dermatitis rather than a specific contact allergen.

Option D: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection characterized by a well-defined, raised, and erythematous rash, usually on the face or lower extremities. It is typically associated with fever and systemic symptoms. The symptoms described in the case, including itching and the positive family history of asthma, are not consistent with erysipelas.

questions.text: When should you schedule the removal of the patch test for an 8-year-old boy who has a previous diagnosis of allergic contact dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B -72 hours:

  • 72 hours: This is the recommended timeframe for patch removal. It allows sufficient time for allergic reactions to occur and helps ensure accurate interpretation of the test results.
  • Contact dermatitis is a delayed hypersensitivity reaction, which can take a few days to appear. Therefore, it is important that a person does a patch test for 96 hours before using new products fully.

 

Incorrect Options: 

Option A - 24 hours: This is too early for patch removal. Allergic reactions may take some time to develop, and 24 hours may not be sufficient for a reaction to manifest.

Option C - 48 Hours:  can be correct , but 72 hours is the upper limit , so better answer.

Option D - 96 hours: This is beyond the recommended timeframe for patch removal. By 96 hours, the patch may have already been on the patient's skin for too long, increasing the risk of skin irritation or adverse reactions.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl presents with itchy lesions on her arm as shown. Her family history is positive for asthma. What could be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Atopic dermatitis:

  • Atopic dermatitis is a chronic inflammatory skin condition characterized by itchy, red, and inflamed skin lesions. It commonly affects individuals with a family history of asthma, allergic rhinitis, or atopic dermatitis .

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Seborrheic dermatitis: Seborrheic dermatitis primarily affects areas rich in sebaceous glands, such as the scalp, face, and chest. It typically presents with greasy, yellowish scales.

Option C - Allergic contact dermatitis: Allergic contact dermatitis occurs when the skin comes into direct contact with an allergen, leading to an allergic reaction.

Option D - Erysipelas: Erysipelas is a bacterial skin infection characterized by a raised, red, and tender rash. It is typically caused by Streptococcus pyogenes and presents with well-defined borders.

questions.text: Bindi Leucoderma is caused by which chemical?

choices.text: Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3

questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Para Tertiary butylphenol (PTBP):

  • Bindi leukoderma, also known as "sticker dermatitis," is caused by the adhesive used in bindis, particularly the chemical PTBP.
  • PTBP is a sensitizing agent that can induce an allergic reaction in some individuals, leading to depigmentation or leucoderma in the area where bindis are applied.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mono-benzyl ether of Hydroquinone (MBH): MBH is not directly associated with bindi leukoderma. While hydroquinone and its derivatives have been implicated in some cases of depigmentation.

Option B - Crocein Scarlet MOO and Solvent Yellow 3: They are commonly used in industries such as textiles and not directly linked to the depigmentation seen in bindi leukoderma.

Option C - P-phenylenediamine (PPD): PPD is a chemical found in hair dyes and is known to cause allergic reactions and contact dermatitis

questions.text: Topical steroids are most effective in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Eczematous dermatitis:

  • Topical steroids are most effective in the treatment of eczematous dermatitis.
  • Eczematous dermatitis refers to a group of inflammatory skin conditions characterized by redness, itching, and scaling. These conditions include atopic dermatitis, contact dermatitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Topical steroids have potent anti-inflammatory properties and are commonly used to reduce inflammation, itching, and redness associated with eczematous dermatitis.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Dermal atrophy: Topical steroids, can cause dermal atrophy, thinning of the skin, and loss of elasticity. This adverse effect is not the desired outcome of treatment.

Option C - Bullous lesion due to HSV: Topical steroids are generally not recommended for the treatment of bullous lesions caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection.s.

Option D - Rosacea: While topical steroids may provide temporary relief for some symptoms of rosacea, they are not considered the primary treatment for this condition.

questions.text: Which component of cement causes allergic dermatitis among construction workers in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Chromate:

  • The correct answer is Chromate. Chromate is a component of cement that can cause allergic dermatitis among construction workers in India.
  • Chromate is a known skin sensitizer, meaning it can cause an allergic reaction upon contact with the skin.
  • Construction workers who handle cement containing chromate can develop allergic dermatitis if they come into contact with the cement repeatedly over time.

 

Incorrect Options:

Option A- Cobalt: While cobalt is used in cement as a drying agent, it is not primarily responsible for causing allergic dermatitis among construction workers.

Option B - Nickel: Nickel is not a component of cement and is not directly responsible for allergic dermatitis in this context.

Option C - Iron: Iron is an essential component of cement, but it is not known to cause allergic dermatitis.
